pages:
Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 41246-01  
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
June 2009 
 
 
 
Capturing Economic Benefits from Ecosystem 
Services 
(Financed by the Japan Special Fund) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  REDD  –  reduced emissions from deforestation and degradation 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  UNFCCC  –  United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change 
      
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development technical assistance (RDTA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Agriculture and natural resources (land-based natural resources 
management, forestry, water-based natural resources 
management)  
Themes (subthemes)  –  Environmental sustainability (natural resources conservation, 
environmental policy and legislation): economic growth (promoting 
economic efficiency and enabling business environment); regional 
cooperation (money and finance , and other regional public goods) 
Climate Change  –  Mitigation  
Location impact  –  Rural (high); national (medium) 
Partnership{s}  –  Center for International Forestry Research and Asia Forest 
Partnership 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  U. Schäfer-Preuss, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development  
Director General  X. Yao, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) 
Unit Head  R.J. Dobias, Climate Change Program Coordination Unit, RSDD 
   
Team leader  D. McCauley, Principal Climate Change Specialist, RSDD 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  It is now widely acknowledged that natural systems such as forests, wetlands, and coral 
reefs provide many important and economically valuable services that are rarely captured by 
markets.  These  ecosystem  services  continue  to  decline  due  to  resource  degradation,  often 
caused by weak property rights, perverse policies, and other market forces.1 
 
2.  The most valuable ecosystem services have been classified into four broad categories: (i) 
carbon sequestration, to mitigate climate change; (ii) watershed protection, to provide clean and 
reliable  water  supplies;  (iii)  biodiversity  conservation,  to  maintain  nature’s  store  of  genetic 
materials for science and to support earth’s life systems; and (iv) land or seascape amenities, to 
support  fisheries,  agriculture,  nature-based  tourism,  and  other  natural  resource  dependent 
industries. 
 
3.  To sustain the provision of these services and the financing needed for management of 
natural systems from which they are derived, market creation approaches are increasingly being 
used. These allow for transactions between those who directly benefit from these services and 
those  in  a  position  to  sustainably  manage  the  forests,  reefs,  or  other  natural  systems.  The 
voluntary  carbon  market,  for  example,  is  financing  forest  protection  to  maintain  carbon 
sequestered from the atmosphere in forests. The Bali road map to a new global climate change 
regime organized under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) 
calls for expanding such efforts through reduced emissions from deforestation and degradation 
(REDD).  
 
4.  Such market mechanisms are being developed around the world, but Asia and the Pacific 
have been less active than others. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) can play a role in helping 
its developing member countries (DMCs) understand and benefit from the new opportunities 
offered by these approaches while managing the accompanying risks. The technical assistance 
(TA) described herein2 will assist with the development of specific applications and guidelines to 
aid their expansion—especially relating to carbon sequestration, watershed protection, and land or 
seascape benefits.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Ecosystems3 provide important services to society, including (i) provisioning services, such 
as food and water; (ii) regulating services, such as regulation of floods, drought, land degradation, 
and disease; (iii) supporting services, such as soil formation and nutrient cycling; and (iv) cultural 
services, such as spiritual, religious, recreational, and other nonmaterial benefits. In the view of 
the  United  Nations  2005  Millennium  Ecosystem  Assessment,  these  services  influence  the 
determinants and constituents of human wellbeing, which include (i) security, (ii) basic material for 
a good life, (iii) health, (iv) good social relations, and (v) freedom and choice. Researchers have 
estimated the annual value of such global ecological services to be in the range of $18 trillion–$61 
trillion. 
 
                                                 
1  Trivedi, Mandar, Andrew Mitchell, and Niki Mardas. 2008. The Utility Value of Rainforests. In Financing Sustainable 
Forest Management (European Tropical Forest Research Network [ETFRN] News Issue No.49, Sept 2008). Edited by 
Holopainen, Jani and Marieke Wit. Waganigen, the Netherlands: Tropenbos International. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on July 2008. 
3  An ecosystem is taken to be a dynamic complex of plant, animal, and microorganism communities, as well as the 
nonliving environment interacting as a functional unit.

2   
6.  Capturing economic benefits from ecosystem services can directly contribute to poverty 
reduction. A recent ADB study4 shows that ecosystem services support the livelihoods and health 
of poor people who are often dependent upon natural systems for their welfare. The stability of 
ecosystem  services  also  underpins  domestic  savings  and  raw  materials  needed  to  further 
economic growth. In many low-income countries, ecosystems and the economic activities they 
support provide products and revenue for daily needs as well as poverty-reducing investments in 
terms of reinvested rural savings, and they are often a principal source of tax revenue to finance 
development programs.  
 
7.  The crucial question is how to finance sustainable and equitable management of these 
valuable ecosystem services so that they are maintained or enhanced. Recent trends show that 
public spending on the environment is declining. For instance, official development assistance for 
sustainable forest management has declined by almost 50% over the last decade on a global 
scale, and support for protected areas has fallen. 
 
8.  In the past, information and market failures have prevented the private sector from using 
market opportunities to support provision of ecosystem services. But today, innovative initiatives, 
backed by necessary flexible regulatory frameworks, have made market exchange of ecosystem 
services possible. Key issues that need to be addressed include (i) demonstrating the value of 
environmental services, both regional and global; (ii) creating methods to monitor them; and (iii) 
ensuring that the market mechanisms promote equity at the individual, community, national, and 
international levels. 
 
9.  Carbon sequestration in particular is likely to play an increasingly important role in post-
2012 global climate change efforts, especially since more than 75% of greenhouse gas emissions 
from countries such as Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, 
and Solomon Islands come from deforestation. REDD systems have the potential to become an 
effective tool for climate change mitigation if their design and implementation maximize benefits to 
poor communities dependent upon forest resources for their livelihoods. The challenge is to 
establish mechanisms that will enable the many potential sellers—including governments, private 
companies  holding  forest  concessions,  and  community  forestry  groups—to  complete  REDD 
applications and validation processes. 
 
10.  ADB has an early and still emerging portfolio of projects that are experimenting with market 
systems for provision of ecosystem services. Recent initiatives include the Indonesia pilot and 
demonstration activities using compensation mechanism for watershed protection services in the 
Citarum River Basin5 with grant funding under the ADB Water Financing Partnership Facility, as 
well  as  the  TA  on  Carbon  Sequestration  through  the  Clean  Development  Mechanism  in 
Indonesia.6 The proposed TA will broaden opportunities for knowledge sharing among these types 
of projects and expand the numbers of complementary pilot activities. 
 
11.  It is envisioned that this TA will form the basis for development of a technical support 
facility  to  aid  such  transactions  and  help  ADB’s  operational  departments  identify  levers  for 
incorporating appreciation for, and the application of markets for, ecosystem services into ADB 
development investments. 
                                                 
4  Steele, Paul, G. Oviedo, D. McCauley. 2007. Poverty, Health, and Ecosystems: Experience in Asia. Manila and 
Gland: ADB and IUCN. 
5  ADB. 2008. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Multitranche 
Financing Facility and Administration of Grant and Technical Assistance Grant to the Republic of Indonesia for the 
Integrated Citarum Water Resources Management Investment Program. Manila. 
6  ADB.  2003.  Technical  Assistance  to  the  Republic  of  Indonesia  for  Carbon  Sequestration  through  the  Clean 
Development Mechanism. Manila.

3
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The goal of this TA is to promote expansion of markets for ecosystem services in Asia and 
the Pacific. The TA is designed to support development of ADB projects at the local, national, and 
regional levels through identification and demonstration of opportunities to include the capture of 
economic  benefits  from  ecosystem  services  in  project  design.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
13.  The specific objectives include the following: 
 
(i)  To raise the level of awareness among key stakeholders about the benefits of 
expanded  markets  for  ecosystem  services  in  responding  to  environment  and 
development goals. 
(ii)  To demonstrate related market and associated policy and institutional mechanisms 
for ecosystem service transactions in selected sites for learning and subsequent 
replication, especially to capture financial transfers through the carbon market.  
(iii)  To identify levers for incorporating appreciation for, and application of markets for, 
ecosystem services into ADB investments. 
 
B.  Approach and Key Activities 
14.  The TA implementation will be linked to ADB TA and project design as well as wider 
country programming, and it will be carried out in direct collaboration with operational departments. 
The TA activities are grouped under four components with corresponding outputs: 
 
(i)  Documentation of mechanisms to create markets for ecosystem services. 
Information  on  existing  mechanisms  will  be  compiled  and  analyzed  to  identify 
lessons learned for application. A compendium of illustrative cases, especially from 
Asia and the Pacific, will be produced. 
(ii)  Identification  of  key  stakeholders.  The  key  stakeholders  will  include 
governments,  conservation  organizations,  indigenous  peoples’  organizations, 
community  forestry  groups,  research  organizations,  practitioners,  and  private 
companies who purchase and sell ecosystem services (such as through the carbon 
market) in local or global markets. This will build on the first component, and an 
improved understanding and registry of key stakeholders will be produced. 
(iii)  National  and  regional  consultations.  To  build  regional  understanding  and 
consensus on promising approaches, a meeting or meetings will be held to learn 
from leading thinkers and practitioners in this field drawn from the region and 
elsewhere. Key resource persons will be scholars, researchers, practitioners, and 
private sector representatives from the range of buyers of ecosystem services. A 
marketplace  function  may  be  considered  if  project  concepts  are  sufficiently 
developed.  The  results  of  all  meetings  will  be  prepared  and  disseminated  as 
knowledge products. 
(iv)  Learning sites. Mechanisms to demonstrate markets for ecosystem services will 
be designed and implemented in selected DMC sites. Such pilot activities will 
address  environmental  goals  (i.e.,  local  and/or  global  sustainability)  and 
development  goals  (i.e.,  livelihood  sustainability  and  poverty  alleviation). 
Documentation of the case studies, in particular lessons learned, will be prepared 
and disseminated.

4   
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is $600,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan 
Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The cost will cover TA consultants and ADB 
staff participating as resource persons in country programming and project missions, national and 
regional conferences and workshops, and publication and information services. The project will 
recruit individual consultants, both international and national. Costs directly accruing to ADB have 
been limited to 10% of the total grant amount. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are 
in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA, and will implement the TA through the 
Regional and Sustainable Development Department’s Climate Change Program Coordination Unit 
in close collaboration with the operational departments. ADB will continue to coordinate closely 
with  other  international  financial  institutions  and  financing  partners,  for  instance  through  its 
involvement in the Poverty and Environment Partnership. The likely DMCs wherein this TA will be 
undertaken are Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines and Greater Mekong Subregion 
countries such as Cambodia, the Lao People's Democratic Republic, and Thailand. Activities 
funded by this TA will begin in a particular DMC only after ADB has received written confirmation 
from the DMC government that it has no objection to its inclusion in the TA. The TA will be 
implemented over 18 months, ideally starting from January 2009.  
 
17.  Consultants to be engaged will bring expertise in the areas of environmental economics, 
ecology, ecosystems management, and the carbon market, among others. Implementation will 
involve national consultants from DMCs to support DMC governments and stakeholders and ADB 
operational departments as necessary. International consultants based at ADB headquarters will 
be recruited to provide further technical support and will work together with national consultants. 
ADB specialist staff will liaise with ADB operational departments as well as with those involved in 
similar initiatives. National consultants within identified DMCs will be engaged for a total of 24 
person-months, and international consultants for 15 person-months. Short-term consultants and 
resource persons will be recruited on an individual basis to fill skills gaps as needed. Individual 
consultants  will  be  engaged  through  either  time-based  or  lump  sum  contracts.  Appendix  3 
presents  the  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consultants.  All  consultants  will  be  recruited  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time).  
 
18.  The TA implementers will coordinate with local embassies of Japan in all phases of the 
project and will work to ensure maximum visibility of Japan Special Fund support as well as 
harmonization  and  coordination  with  other  Government  of  Japan-supported  initiatives  in  the 
identified DMCs. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The  President,  acting under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis for 
Capturing Economic Benefits from Ecosystem Services, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   Consulting Services 
 
1.  Multidisciplinary  international  and  national  consultants  with  extensive  experience  in 
market  capture  of  ecosystems  services  and associated research  and  management  will  be 
required  for  this  technical  assistance  (TA).  National  consultants  will  be  familiar  with  local 
conditions,  institutional  structures,  and  economic  trends.  International  consultants  will  be 
required to collaborate with, and supplement the skills of, the national consultants. About 15 
person-months of international consulting services and 24 person-months of national consulting 
services are projected. Consultants will be engaged in accordance with the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
2.  The consulting team will provide the services outlined in the TA report and will ensure 
that all work and outputs under the TA comply fully with relevant ADB policies and guidelines. 
The  consultants  will  be  under  the  overall  supervision  of  the  head  of  the  Climate  Change 
Program  Coordination  Unit,  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department.  The 
consultants  are  expected  to  be  familiar  with  ADB’s  guidelines  for  technical,  financial,  and 
economic  analyses,  and  social  safeguards.  The  TA  consultants  will  develop  and  use  a 
comprehensive evaluation framework for all stakeholder meetings and workshops to determine 
their effectiveness. 
 
B.   Scope of Work 
 
3.  Responsibilities of each consultant will include, but no necessarily be limited to, the 
following tasks: 
 
1.  International Consultants  
 
a.  Payment for Ecosystem Services Specialist and Team Leader (12 
person-months) 
(i)  Analyze ecosystem services provision and existing mechanisms 
related to payments for ecosystem services in Asia through review 
of existing literature and meetings; in collaboration with national 
consultants. 
(ii)  Identify  economic  and  ecological  lessons  learned  from  case 
studies and develop the synthesis report. 
(iii)  Provide  direction  to  national  consultants  and  offer  technical 
support, particularly in the development of process and method for 
selecting and documenting learning sites. 
(iv)  Assign national consultants to engage the selected learning sites. 
(v)  Oversee the organization of the regional workshop. 
(vi)  Develop concepts with ADB and identified developing member 
countries (DMCs) as a result of opportunities identified during the 
regional workshop; in partnership with national consultants. 
(vii)  Participate  in  regional  and  country  programming  missions  as 
necessary. 
 
b.  Communications Specialist (3 person-months) 
(i)  Package results from meetings, workshops, and learning sites as 
knowledge products.

Appendix 3  9 
(ii)  Produce  a  consolidated  registry  of  stakeholders  from  all  the 
identified DMCs and learning sites. 
(iii)  Assist the team leader in finalizing the synthesis report. 
(iv)  Ensure widespread dissemination of knowledge gained. 
(v)  Provide technical and other TA-related assistance to the team 
leader and national consultants and various ADB departments and 
offices with regard to payments for ecosystem services. 
 
2.  National Consultants  
 
a.  Project Coordinator (11 person-months) 
(i)  Develop a detailed work plan and budget for the TA and provide 
assistance with its overall implementation. 
(ii)  Provide technical and other TA-related assistance to international 
and  national  consultants  and  various  ADB  departments  and 
offices with regard to payments for ecosystem services. 
(iii)  Participate in the regional workshop and stakeholder meetings 
and assist in documenting the proceedings of these events. 
(iv)  Prepare monthly and quarterly technical reports on TA operations 
for submission to Management as well as reports for submission 
to  the  Japan  Special  Fund  through  the  Office  of  Cofinancing 
Operations. 
(v)  Perform other related tasks assigned by the team leader and the 
head of the Climate Change Program Coordination Unit. 
 
b.  National Specialists (13 person-months) 
(i)  Compile existing mechanisms related to payments for ecosystems 
services in Asia through review of existing literature and meetings 
in collaboration with the team leader, and provide inputs to the 
identification of lessons learned. 
(ii)  Collect and organize data on system ecology, economic valuation 
of ecosystem services, and barriers and incentives to participation 
in ecosystem service markets. 
(iii)  Identify learning sites in collaboration with the team leader and 
produce a registry of key stakeholders in the learning site where 
the consultant is assigned. 
(iv)  Organize stakeholder meetings as venues for buyers and sellers 
in the identified DMCs and learning sites in order to exchange 
information  on  concepts  and  mechanisms  for  payments  for 
environmental services. 
(v)  Assist  in  organizing  the  regional  workshop  and  possible 
marketplace  function,  depending  upon  the  number  of  project 
concepts developed. 
(vi)  Develop  concepts  describing  markets  and/or  payment 
mechanisms  that  cover  all  the  broad  categories  of  ecosystem 
services for implementation in the DMC site or learning site where 
the  consultant  is  assigned,  addressing  both  local  and  global 
environmental and developmental goals. 
(vii)  Assist  the  team  leader  in  drafting  proposals  with  ADB  and 
identified DMCs and learning sites as a result of opportunities 
identified during the regional workshop.

  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  REDD  –  reduced emissions from deforestation and degradation 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  UNFCCC  –  United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change 
      
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development technical assistance (RDTA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Agriculture and natural resources (land-based natural resources 
management, forestry, water-based natural resources 
management)  
Themes (subthemes)  –  Environmental sustainability (natural resources conservation, 
environmental policy and legislation): economic growth (promoting 
economic efficiency and enabling business environment); regional 
cooperation (money and finance , and other regional public goods) 
Climate Change  –  Mitigation

Partnership{s}  –  Center for International Forestry Research and Asia Forest 
Partnership
